articles.headline: In Solar Power, India Begins Living Up to Its Own Ambitions
articles.snippet: Two years ago, India said it would drastically increase its use of solar power by 2020. Many analysts said it couldn’t be done. Now they aren’t so sure.
articles.abstract: Two years ago, India said it would drastically increase its use of solar power by 2020. Many analysts said it couldn’t be done. Now they aren’t so sure.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHADODA, India — Solar power is a clean energy source. But in this arid part of northwest India it can also be a dusty one.

articles.headline: Award Time for Ideas That Shine
articles.snippet: The Pogie Awards are given to the best tech ideas of the year, even if the products aren’t that hot. And the winners are. ...
articles.abstract: The Pogie Awards are given to the best tech ideas of the year, even if the products aren’t that hot. And the winners are. ...
articles.lead_paragraph: Yes, it’s the end of the year, and you know what that means: plucking shredded gift wrap off the rug, making New Year’s resolutions and learning to stop writing “2011” on personal checks.

articles.headline: Weapons Sales to Iraq Move Ahead Despite U.S. Worries
articles.snippet: Some fear that American weapons will strengthen Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s apparent efforts to consolidate his power and establish Shiite dominance.
articles.abstract: Some fear that American weapons will strengthen Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s apparent efforts to consolidate his power and establish Shiite dominance.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The Obama administration is moving ahead with the sale of nearly $11 billion worth of arms and training for the Iraqi military despite concerns that Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki is seeking to consolidate authority, create a one-party Shiite-dominated state and abandon the American-backed power-sharing government.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Instead of Work, Younger Women Head to School
articles.snippet: Many young women are leaving the labor force to upgrade their skills, while their male counterparts are more likely to take whatever job they can find.
articles.abstract: Many young women are leaving the labor force to upgrade their skills, while their male counterparts are more likely to take whatever job they can find.
articles.lead_paragraph: Workers are dropping out of the labor force in droves, and they are mostly women. In fact, many are young women. But they are not dropping out forever; instead, these young women seem to be postponing their working lives to get more education. There are now — for the first time in three decades — more young women in school than in the work force.

articles.headline: Oakland’s Reins Blister a Mayor Raised on Protest
articles.snippet: For Mayor Jean Quan, a longtime civil rights activist and former union organizer, the possibility of being undone by youthful demonstrators poses a painful paradox.
articles.abstract: For Mayor Jean Quan, a longtime civil rights activist and former union organizer, the possibility of being undone by youthful demonstrators poses a painful paradox.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Days after Jean Quan was elected mayor in the fall of 2010, the Oakland police put a wheel clamp on her silver Prius while it was parked outside City Hall. She cursed her husband for not paying the family’s parking tickets and braced for the embarrassing news articles.

articles.headline: Oil Prices Predicted to Stay Above $100 a Barrel Through Next Year
articles.snippet: Analysts say higher global demand and possible supply problems from Iran could keep the price for a barrel of oil in the triple digits.
articles.abstract: Analysts say higher global demand and possible supply problems from Iran could keep the price for a barrel of oil in the triple digits.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States economy managed to cope this year despite triple-digit prices for barrels of oil. The lessons may come in handy, economists say, because those prices will probably be sticking around.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Rick Gladstone

articles.headline: In One Slum, Misery, Work, Politics and Hope
articles.snippet: More than a warehouse for the poor, Dharavi, a Mumbai slum, contains a hive of workshops with an annual economic output of more than $600 million.
articles.abstract: More than a warehouse for the poor, Dharavi, a Mumbai slum, contains a hive of workshops with an annual economic output of more than $600 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — At the edge of India’s greatest slum, Shaikh Mobin’s decrepit shanty is cleaved like a wedding cake, four layers high and sliced down the middle. The missing half has been demolished. What remains appears ready for demolition, too, with temporary walls and a rickety corrugated roof.

articles.headline: Marching Orders for Paul’s Volunteers: Do Shave, Don’t Tweet
articles.snippet: Strict orders to young Iowa supporters: Look, dress, shave, sound and behave in a way that will not jeopardize Ron Paul’s chances.
articles.abstract: Strict orders to young Iowa supporters: Look, dress, shave, sound and behave in a way that will not jeopardize Ron Paul’s chances.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Ron Paul’s college-aged volunteer army — a core of the powerful ground organization that is the envy of rivals — is descending on Iowa from around the nation to coax people to the state’s Republican caucuses as he seeks to pull off what only months ago seemed like an unthinkable victory here on Tuesday.
